reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>Long ago</vocabulary>, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "<reading>Heesa</reading> (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."

To remember this reading, just think about what your mommy did for you when you were little and you got yourself a <vocabulary>wound</vocabulary>... she would <reading>kiss</reading> (きず) the wounds better. Of course, that never worked and was a total farce, but try to forgive mommy this one time, okay?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes そ to ぞ！
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.
The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

The most <vocabulary>strict</vocabulary> creature in Japan is the <reading>key bee</reading> (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!
Think about that really <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>private</vocabulary> dude. <reading>He so</reading> (ひそ) secret...
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that みつ changes to みっ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

When you have the <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary> to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say <reading>心ざし</reading> (こころざし), which is how this word was written in classical Japanese. In modern Japanese it's always 志, but the reading is exactly the same. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You know what's really scary? <reading>Koa</reading>las (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is the same as 押す.
The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary> that bit of knowledge just yet!

When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: <reading>とる</reading>.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is the same as 温かい, which also means <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>. But while that 温かい refers to a warm thing, this 暖かい refers to a warm temperature or place.

Just like with 温かい, people often pronounce this as あったかい in conversation. But when it comes to kanji exams or typing out the kanji, remember to use あたたかい!
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
You need <vocabulary>to dye</vocabulary> something that you just <reading>sew</reading>ed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading comes from the kanji.
The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.
The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Things seem <vocabulary>to get dirty</vocabulary> easily around here, which is why <reading>you go</reading> (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean.

Note that the reading よごれる is generally used for getting physically dirty, whereas けがれる is more figurative, so more like “to be defiled”.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary> and you won't have a <reading>care</reading> (かれる) in the world!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a <vocabulary>burn</vocabulary> (on your arm) being caused by a <reading>yakky do</reading>do (やけど) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.

The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing:

When are you going <vocabulary>to feel hot</vocabulary>? When is your face going <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary>? When I ask you to go to a <reading>hotel</reading> (ほてる) with me!
The reading comes from 照る and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.
The reading is the vocab 生 and 卵 combined into one <reading>なまたまご</reading>.
You'll have to be careful about this one, as it's actually read with the two kanji's kun'yomi readings put together, making this しろはた.
The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary> had a <reading>bo</reading>at (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.

The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing <vocabulary>to conceal</vocabulary> about this reading, you gots it.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!
The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.
The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What's your <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary> to <reading>wake</reading> (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?

The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is the same as 越える. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic:

<vocabulary>To go beyond</vocabulary> <reading>child</reading> (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.
Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here.

<vocabulary>To pick someone up</vocabulary> you are going to drive your <reading>moo ca</reading>r. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You learned this reading when you learned 遊ぶ. It's the same one!
Something was so <vocabulary>sour</vocabulary> that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to <reading>sue</reading> (す) the maker of this nasty sour thing.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is <reading>ぜに</reading>. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the <vocabulary>public bath</vocabulary>, you're in <reading>To</reading>kyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need someone <vocabulary>to look after</vocabulary> your kids for the day. Hey, I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at <reading>a zoo</reading> (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your <reading>car</reading>s (か) for the day!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of <reading>ca</reading>t!
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary.

The second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

At the height of <vocabulary>showing off</vocabulary>, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.
